OPERATIVE SUMMARY: The patient underwent bronchoscopy for management of persistent air leak. 
COMPLICATION: Following deployment of a Zephyr valve in RB1, the patient developed acute tension pneumothorax. 
MANAGEMENT: Emergent needle decompression and tube thoracostomy (32551) were performed. Hemodynamics stabilized. 
REVISION: A second valve was placed in RB3 to mitigate collateral flow. 
STATUS: Critical care admission required.

67890123:
BRONCHOSCOPY REPORT: ENDOBRONCHIAL VALVE PLACEMENT WITH COMPLICATIONS
[REDACTED]

Patient: [REDACTED] "Hal" Johnson | DOB: [REDACTED] | Age: 74 | MRN: [REDACTED]
Institution: [REDACTED]
Physician: Dr. Priya Patel, MD, FCCP
CT Surgery Consultant: Dr. Robert Chen, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin Wu, MD

INDICATION: Severe COPD with giant bulla RUL, persistent air leak following RUL bullectomy

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement for persistent air leak management

CONSENT: Extended discussion regarding use of valves for air leak (off-label indication). Risks discussed including valve migration, persistent air leak, infection, bleeding, respiratory failure. Patient and family understood and agreed.

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient [REDACTED] IP suite with existing chest tube in place demonstrating persistent air leak (large continuous bubbling). Pre-procedure chest CT reviewed showing large residual apical cavity communicating with RUL bronchi.

Moderate sedation achieved. Flexible bronchoscopy revealed:
- Normal larynx and trachea
- RUL: Visualization of communication between RB1 and apical cavity
- Active "sucking" noted at RB1 entrance correlating with air leak

INTERVENTION:
Attempted placement of 5.5mm Zephyr valve in RB1. Initial deployment appeared satisfactory.

COMPLICATION:
Immediately following valve placement, patient developed acute desaturation to 82% on 4L NC. Simultaneously noted increase in subcutaneous emphysema and asymmetric chest wall movement. Immediately suspected tension pneumothorax.

MANAGEMENT:
- Procedure aborted
- 100% O2 applied
- Emergency portable CXR confirmed large right-sided pneumothorax with mediastinal shift
- Cardiothoracic surgery emergently consulted
- Second chest tube placed (28Fr) with immediate improvement
- Patient stabilized

ADDITIONAL VALVE PLACEMENT:
After stabilization and with CT surgery at bedside, decision made to place additional valve in RB3 to reduce overall flow into cavity.
- 4.0mm valve placed in RB3 without incident
- Air leak notably reduced but not eliminated

FINAL ASSESSMENT:
- Partial success: Air leak reduced from large to moderate
- Complication: Iatrogenic pneumothorax requiring second chest tube
- Both chest tubes to suction with water seal

POST-PROCEDURE PLAN:
- ICU admission  
- Serial CXRs
- Consider additional valve placement if air leak persists after 72 hours
- Family meeting held, understanding confirmed

Priya Patel, MD, FCCP
Interventional Pulmonology
Stanford Medical Center

Attending Note: Complex case with expected high-risk given bullous disease. Appropriate emergency management of complication. Will follow closely. - PP
